I mean not seeing or hearing another person yawning nearby, but for some reason it's still contagious. I've witnessed it many times, and I've always wondered why it happens. When I was a kid I thought maybe it's because that big breath that one person takes reduces the amount of oxygen in the area so other people naturally yawn to take in more air. I know now that that was a ridiculous theory, but at the time it seemed to make sense.

My theory on the contagious yawn: Even though the common yawn as a sign of tiredness/and or the body looking for more air, I believe it's "contagious" due to instinctual traits from learning how to swim. I wouldn't imply that being autistic means someone lacks empathy.  A lot of people on the spectrum actually feel an excess of emotional empathy (separate from cognitive empathy, which is the kind autistics tend to lack).  I'm on the spectrum and I am "hyperempathetic."  Autistics simply express our empathy in a different way than most people.  This difference of expression may also contribute to the frequency of autistic people's yawns vs. that of most people, though I haven't studied it, and so I can't say.   All that aside, the "lack of empathy" stereotype about autistic people is both corrosive to our reputation and largely untrue, so I felt like I had to say something.

I have what I call "compulsive yawning", which means that sometimes, I will yawn, whether I've stayed up too long, or am bored with things, or just woke up, and if I don't complete the first yawn, I will continue to yawn, every few minutes, for up to 6 hours straight. I've also had a similar problem when I walk or exercise. When i take a walk, due to the physical exertion I am producing, combined with my asthma and the hot temperatures of where I live, I'll continuously yawn every 5-10 minutes until i stop walking. And no matter what, i can't control it. it will happen every time I walk long distances, even if I try to prevent it from happening.

I can't believe that the term "mirror neurons" was never mentioned in this video. They are assumed to be responsible for empathy, yawning and many more abilities that make us understand how other people feel or think. Thanks to them, we can even predict where a person is walking so we don't bump into them. Authists, who lack a certain amount of mirror neurons, therefore have major trouble with all those abilities. You should make a vid about them (I'm pretty sure there isn't one yet)

I know it's natural for humans to try and clump information under a single explanation to better understand it, but really I think yawning has multiple purposes. Yes it helps us stay alert but I think that's a confusion between cause and effect.

Yawning is mostly associated with fatigue. Yawning increases heart rate (thus blood flow) and helps us relax. Due to this increase in blood flow and oxygen, we are also more alert.

I think becoming alert is a side-effect of yawning instead of a cause.

This, I yawn when strength training.
I predict it doesn't happen as much with running because we already breathe a lot during the run. But if you hold your breath for any certain amount of time while lifting (or anything similar) then you will probably need that yawn.

Yawning is contagious because your Brain thinks that a yawn is either when your brain needs oxygen/cooling or your system is shutting down getting ready to sleep.

"Oh! Their system is shutting down, I best shut mine down to! Cause it must be ready to sleep!"

If children with autism yawn less often that doesn't make it a factor of empathy, despite misconceptions autistic people have as much empathy as people who are 'neuro-typical'. The fact is that people with autism, particularly those who are on the milder end of the spectrum such as those with Asperger's syndrome, experience the same emotions and feelings as neuro-typicals but rather don't respond instinctively in the same way that others normally would which may make them seem less empathetic.

The empathy leading to contagious yawning comes from mirror neurons in the brain. When you yawn, neurons fire in your brain, just like when doing any other activity, and since the brain cannot tell the difference between you and others, many of the same neurons will fire in the brain of the observer, making them likely to yawn as well. Actually, the fact is oxygen has very little to do with whether or not we want to take a breath. The primary urge to breathe (more precisely: to exhale) is triggered by rising carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the bloodstream.CO2 builds up in the bloodstream when O2 is metabolized and it needs to be expelled as a waste product. The body detects CO2 levels very accurately and relies on this to control breathing.
